greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) is the number of divisors of n whose last digit equals the last digit of n.
comment: Inspired by Project Euler, Problem 474 (see link).
When n > 10 ends with 0, 1, 2 or 5, then a(n) >= 2.
The 19 first terms are the same as A038769, but a(20) = 2 and A038769(20) = 1.
If n is odd, then a(2*n) = a(n) and a(5*n) = A000005(n). (End)
Integers all of whose divisors end with the same last digit (which is necessarily 1) are in A004615. - _Bernard Schott_, May 07 2021
link: Robert Israel, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
Project Euler, Problem 474: Last digits of divisors
example: The divisors of 12 that end in 2 are 2 and 12, so a(12) = 2.
mathematica: a[n_] := DivisorSum[n, 1 &, Mod[# - n, 10] == 0 &]; Array[a, 100] (* _Amiram Eldar_, Jun 04 2020 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = my(u=n%10); sumdiv(n, d, (d%10) == u); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Jun 04 2020
results.author: _Bernard Schott_, Jun 04 2020
